knowledge_chain.query: Which shapes are used in the slide to illustrate the closure aspect of the Gestalt Principle of Visual Perception?
knowledge_chain.raw_result:
The slide illustrates the **Closure** aspect of the Gestalt Principle of Visual Perception using several specific shapes and arrangements:

- **Incomplete Circle**: Composed of six short, curved line segments arranged radially, this figure creates the illusion of a whole circle as the viewerâ€™s mind fills in the missing gaps.
- **Incomplete Rectangle**: Made up of eight straight line segments (two vertical and two horizontal per side) with consistent spacing, it gives the impression of a continuous rectangular boundary despite its fragmented form.
- **Pac-Man-Like Figures**: Three black geometric shapes resembling circles with triangular wedges removed are arranged so that their negative space forms an **Equilateral Triangle**, demonstrating how closure allows perception of a complete shape from incomplete elements.
- **Starburst Pattern**: Created by multiple black triangular spikes radiating outward from a **Central Circular Void**, this pattern exemplifies the Law of Good Gestalt but also relies on closure to be perceived as a unified, orderly whole.

These shapes are typically presented against a plain white or light gray background to enhance contrast and emphasize perceptual completion. They appear in diagrams such as the *Gestalt Closure Principle Diagram*, *Gestalt Closure Illusion Diagram*, and *Minimalist Black-And-White Line Drawing*, all designed to visually demonstrate how the human brain organizes fragmented visual information into coherent wholes.

These are presented in black-and-white diagrams to highlight how the brain perceives complete shapes from fragmented elements.
